                Fiorina, pictured in 1999, says on the campaign trail that she had to burn down Hewlett Packard in order to save it. | AP Photo

                        On the campaign trail, the details of her time as a Fortune 500 CEO go mostly unmentioned.

            By 
Eli Stokols

09/24/15 01:15 PM EDT
COLUMBIA, S.C. — Carly Fiorina’s business background is an essential part of the story she tells on the campaign trail, offering an “only in America” biographical tale of her journey from secretary to CEO. Yet the crowning achievement of her corporate career -- her tenure as a Fortune 500 CEO at Hewlett-Packard -- isn't central to her stump speech.
Repeating the same lines from stop to stop, Fiorina rails against an "inept, corrupt bureaucracy." She offers herself up as a leader who understands the intersection of business and technology, a “fierce fighter” resolved to tip the scales back toward average people in an economy overrun by "crony capitalism."
Story Continued Below
"Only someone who understands how a bureaucracy works can cut it down to size,” she told a crowd of 200 people at a barbecue joint in Lexington Wednesday.
The details of her Hewlett-Packard story go mostly unmentioned -- and her audiences don't seem to mind. In five events in South Carolina over the last three days, she took more than a dozen questions but only once was she pressed about her HP service by someone other than a reporter.



            By 
Eli Stokols

"Yes, I've been widely criticized by Democrats and Donald Trump," Fiorina acknowledged Thursday to the questioner, deflecting the issue. Only when the questioner persisted did she paint a fuller picture of her view of her time at Hewlett-Packard, comparing HP to other companies that perished when the tech bubble burst. She likening herself to other innovators and executives — Oprah Winfrey, Walt Disney and Steve Jobs — who had all been fired at one point.
"I got fired in a boardroom brawl that lasted about two weeks," she explained. "Why? Because when you lead and you challenge the status quo, you make enemies. Steve Jobs called me that day and said, 'Been there, done that, twice.'"
For her surging candidacy, HP is nevertheless emerging as the elephant in the room, a subject of personal pride for the candidate but also an enormous political liability. In Fiorina's only prior run for office, Democratic Sen. Barbara Boxer’s campaign weaponized the issue to devastating effect, framing the former CEO's tenure as a time marked by the layoffs of 30,000 employees and the company loss of half its value before Fiorina left with a $100 million golden parachute.
Her current rivals have zeroed in on her vulnerability, using Boxer's scorching attacks as a template. In last week's debate, Donald Trump told Fiorina he would never hire her to run one of his companies, citing a Yale business professor's indictment of her tenure at Hewlett Packard as “one of the worst tenures for a CEO that he has ever seen.”
That professor, Jeffrey Sonnenfeld, weighed in with a scathing op-ed for Politico magazine this week, affirming Trump's characterization of his view. "It was Fiorina’s failed leadership that brought her company down," he wrote.
His assessment hit a nerve: Fiorina's campaign manager responded to Sonnenfeld's treatise with a personal attack of sorts, drawing reporters' attention to 15-year-old allegations of vandalism against the professor dating back to his forced resignation from Emory University's business school.
“I’ll give Sonnenfeld this: He would know something about getting fired,” wrote Sarah Isgur Flores, Fiorina's deputy campaign manager, in an email to reporters. 
In a post on Medium Tuesday, Fiorina’s campaign manager offered 10 data points pushing back at “armchair CEO’ing,” arguing that Fiorina’s decisions saved 80,000 jobs and led the company to double its revenues.
On the campaign trail, though, Fiorina's response to questions doesn't deviate much — boiled down to its essence, her argument is that she had to burn down Hewlett Packard in order to save it.
"I was recruited to Hewlett Packard to save the company and I did that and we saved a lot of jobs in the process," Fiorina said Wednesday afternoon during a press gaggle after she officially signed paperwork ensuring her place on South Carolina’s Feb. 20 primary ballot.
"I look forward to people challenging me on my record because I'll run on it all day long,” she continued.



            By 
Nick Gass

Fiorina bristles at comparisons to Mitt Romney, whom Democrats pilloried in 2012 as an out-of-touch plutocrat by highlighting the wealth he amassed during his tenure at Bain Capital, the Boston-based global investment firm he founded.
The attacks against Romney mirrored Boxer’s television ads from two years earlier, which portrayed Fiorina as a heartless executive who walked away with a huge severance deal. Boxer lambasted Fiorina’s choice “to become a CEO, lay off 30,000 workers, ship jobs overseas [and] have two yachts” -- Fiorina didn’t help matters when she responded by explaining that she and her husband had two yachts because they spent time in both California and Washington. Despite the GOP wave, Fiorina lost by 10 percentage points.
Carly for America, the super PAC that is responsible for much of the political infrastructure undergirding Fiorina’s actual campaign, has stepped in to shore up her defenses, releasing a film featuring interviews with Hewlett-Packard colleagues putting a positive gloss on her record as a CEO.
On Tuesday, when the “Citizen Carly” film premiered in Virginia, Fiorina pushed back at a reporter in Myrtle Beach who suggested a similarity between her record and Romney’s.
"My business experience is quite different than Mitt Romney's,” she said. “Bain Capital is not the same as running a company. I didn't have a basket of companies that I could look over; I had one company that I was asked to lead. In fact, I was recruited by the board to save a company and that's what we did in a very difficult time.
Fiorina's stiff spine has served her well thus far. But rival campaigns are circulating opposition research and readying new attacks. Now that she's nipping at his heels in the polls, Trump has continued to pick at her business record. This week, Politifact rated his statement dismissing Fiorina’s boasting of raising revenues as the result of HP purchase of Compaq -- which Trump contends “led to the destruction of the company” -- mostly true.
“She’s riding high right now, but this can all end pretty quickly,” said an adviser to another Republican campaign. “We saw the potency of this attack in California. There’s no reason to think it won’t be potent again.”
Eli Stokols is a national politics reporter.
